#Text=Plymouth ( England )
#Text=Plymouth is a city in Devon , and the largest city on England 's south coast , with a population of 250,000 .

#Text=It is located approximately 190 miles ( 310 km ) south-west of London , where the River Plym and the River Tamar ( pronounced " TAY-mar " ) flow into the large bay of Plymouth Sound , creating a perfect natural harbour .

column1: #Text=The sea has been at the heart of Plymouth since it was founded in the middle-ages as a trading post and the source of its prosperity .
#Text=Plymouth was the point from which the Pilgrim Fathers left England in 1620 for Massachusetts - commemorated today in the Mayflower Steps .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Plymouth is one of England 's classic ocean cities , and for centuries has been a centre for shipping ; first for trade and commercial shipping , and today as a base for the Royal Navy .
#Text=Indeed , the city 's Devonport Dockyard is the most extensive naval base in western Europe .
#Text=The water , with its leisure activities , brings many tourists to Plymouth , as well as its various museums and other tourist attractions .
#Text=In addition its location close to Dartmoor and other sights of south Devon to the east and Cornwall to the west make it an excellent base for a trip to the south-west of England .
#Text=The city was heavily bombed in World War II and much of the city-centre was destroyed .

#Text=After the war , a comprehensive reconstruction plan at first produced the carefully-planned urban spaces and elegant buildings of the shopping streets in the city centre , constructed in the 1950s .

#Text=However , due to budget restrictions many of the buildings erected in the 1960s and 70s were of poor architectural quality , and these are now being torn down and replaced across the city by modern ones ( with exceptions of some quality , such as the listed tower of the Civic Centre on the Royal Parade ) .
#Text=As a result , there are many modern buildings with others under construction .

#Text=Plymouth is a friendly city with an egalitarian feel and a sense of openness among its people , and there is less evidence of a sharp divide between rich and poor that is found in much of the southern half of England .

#Text=Wonderful Devon and Cornwall scenery surrounds the city and famous city locations , such as the Hoe , the Barbican , and Plymouth Sound draw thousands every year yet Plymouth does n't have the " tourist trap " feel that hangs over many other English cities .

column1: #Text=For those who love the sea , or the coast , or the brooding landscapes of Dartmoor , or just want a break in a welcoming and interesting city , Plymouth is an enticing and friendly destination .
#Text=A resident of Plymouth is called a Plymothian .
#Text=You may also hear the more derogatory term " Janner " being used - but do n't call anyone this if you are a visitor !

#Text=There is a large military presence in the city , with the Royal Navy 's main base at Devonport , a commando regiment of the British Army at the Royal Citadel , and a Royal Marines base at Stonehouse .
#Text=In addition , you 'll likely find a lot of tourists and students .
#Text=Orientation
#Text=The city is located at the south-west corner of Devon , with Cornwall beginning immediately to the west of the city .

#Text=It lies between two river mouths - the estuary of the River Tamar ( " TAY-mar " ) to the west ( the estuary is called the Hamoaze ) and the estuary of the River Plym to the east ( called the Cattewater ) .

#Text=To the south is Plymouth Sound ( everyone just calls it " the Sound " ) , a large bay bounded to the west by the Rame Peninsula which is now part of Cornwall , and to the east by the Mount Batten Peninsula .

#Text=This produces one of the world 's most impressive natural harbours , in which you 'll see innumerable yachts , sailing ships , kayaks , other pleasure craft , and even small fishing vessels ( of which there are a reasonable number in Plymouth ) .
#Text=The Sound is protected from the sea by a huge breakwater at its southern end , easily seen from the shore .
#Text=You 'll often see naval vessels around it .
#Text=Immediately above the water is a grassy area called Plymouth Hoe ( always just called " the Hoe " ) , whose names comes from a Saxon word for " grassy slope " .
#Text=You can spot the Hoe easily because of the lighthouse ( Smeaton 's Tower ) that sits on it , and its wide grassy area .

#Text=From here , planned as part of the grand reconstruction of the 1950s , runs north the " spine " of the city - from Smeaton 's Tower on the Hoe , to the railway station north of the city-centre ( which you can identify from its 1970s tower , InterCity House ) .
#Text=This " spine " is Armada Way , a wide street , mostly pedestrianised , with council offices at its southern end , and shops and banks and cafés as you head north .

#Text=Running east-west across Armada Way are other important city-centre streets with their elegant yet now-faded buildings ; Royal Parade , New George Street , Cornwall Street , and Mayflower Street .
#Text=These city-centre streets are bounded by busy main roads .

#Text=To the east of the Hoe is the Barbican area ( with its historic streets and large harbour/marina ) , and the University of Plymouth 's large and impressive campus is just across the main road at the north-east of the city-centre .
#Text=Other major streets can be found off these .
#Text=The Tourist Information Centre is in the Barbican area , at the quayside just opposite the Mayflower Steps , at 3-5 The Barbican ( that 's the street address ) .
#Text=It is open 9AM-5PM on weekdays and 10AM-4PM on Saturdays , all year .
#Text=Background
#Text=Plymouth City is within the historic county of Devon .
#Text=The area was first recorded in the Domesday book as " Sudtone " ( 1086 ; later Sutton ) , which was located where the Barbican area of the city is today .
#Text=Around this time also existed the trading port of Plymstock , further up the river ( it still exists today as a suburb ) .
#Text=However , the River Plym at Plymstock silted up in the 11th century and the area gradually came to be known as " Plymouth " .
#Text=The sea has always been at the heart of Plymouth 's story and it has a long and historic seafaring tradition .

#Text=Its growth from a small fishing village and then trading port has been based on its position on one of the world 's largest natural harbours and the enterprise of its seafarers - fishermen , merchants , privateers and later the Royal Navy .

#Text=Plymouth was the home of Elizabethan privateer and hero/villain Sir Francis Drake ( though he was born at Tavistock a few miles north ) , and from here he planned his raids and other maritime adventures .
#Text=In 1588 , the English Navy , which was led in part by Drake , set sail from Plymouth to defeat the Spanish Armada .
#Text=It is said that Drake refused to leave port until he had finished his game of bowls on the Hoe .
#Text=While this is probably more legend than history , there is still a bowls club on the Hoe today .
#Text=In 1620 the Pilgrim Fathers sailed to the New World after setting into Plymouth for repairs , escaping from religious persecution to eventually set up Plymouth Colony , Massachusetts .
#Text=Plymouth was a stronghold of Parliamentarian forces in the English Civil War , written across its history in areas such as Freedom Fields park .
#Text=After the restoration , the new king , Charles II , ordered the construction of a massive fort ( the Royal Citadel ) to protect the town from invaders - such was its strategic importance .
#Text=But the fort 's guns also faced inland , it is said as a signal to the people of the city about where their loyalties should lie !
#Text=The Royal Citadel is still home to a unit of the Army .
#Text=The Royal Dockyard was built in the area , on the banks of the River Tamar , in 1690 .
#Text=Plymouth was amalgamated in 1914 with the towns of Devonport and Stonehouse to form the modern city which was granted city status in 1928 .
#Text=It includes the historic areas of Plymstock and Plympton .
#Text=The city was seriously damaged by bombing during the Second World War ( 1939 – 45 ) and the city-centre was extensively redeveloped afterwards .
#Text=At Charles Cross , the ruined Charles Church was left as a memorial to the many dead .
#Text=Behind it , the Drake Circus shopping centre was constructed to frame it in dramatic fashion , as an impressive entrance to the city from the south-east .
#Text=The shopping streets of the city-centre were first to be reconstructed , according to the grand plan of Sir Patrick Abercrombie .
#Text=This resulted in the elegant large buildings from the 1950s that can be seen on streets such as Armada Way , New George Street , and Cornwall Street .
#Text=However , these are now in need of restoration .
#Text=Much of the rest of the reconstruction involved cheap buildings in the Brutalist style fashionable in the 1960s and 1970s , most of which had no architectural merit .
#Text=However , exceptions included the Civic Centre which is Grade II-listed .

#Text=Many historic buildings remain , particularly in the Barbican area , isolated city-centre examples such as the City Museum , and also outside the city-centre which escaped the worst of the bombing ( e.g. the Royal William Yard ) .
#Text=With its dramatic coastal setting , the surrounding landscape is quite striking .
#Text=Plymouth is by turns rugged and hilly , or green and rolling .
#Text=Famous Dartmoor was designated a National Park in 1951 .

#Text=Popular sites include Smeaton 's Tower ( a lighthouse rebuilt on the Hoe from its original location at Eddystone Rock when it was replaced with a new one ) , the Mount Batten Peninsula , the National Marine Aquarium , and Buckland Abbey , which was Drake 's former home .
#Text=Tourism is an important aspect of Plymouth 's economy .
#Text=Nearly 12 million people visit Plymouth every year .

#Text=As well as all the attractions of a modern city , Plymouth is a popular launch pad to other notable areas including the beaches and footpaths of the Devon and Cornwall coastline and the brooding landscape of nearby Dartmoor .
